metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Array Iteration
Array Iteration Methods
Array iteration methods operate on every array item:
content.html: Array iteration methods operate on every array item:

Array forEach
Array map()
Array flatMap()
Array filter()
Array reduce()
Array reduceRight()

See Also:

Basic Array Methods
Array Search Methods
Array Sort Methods 		Array every()
Array some()
Array from()
Array keys()
Array entries()
Array with()
Array Spread (...)

content.text: JavaScript Array forEach()
The forEach() method calls a function (a callback function) once for each array element.
content.html: The forEach() method calls a function (a callback function) once for each array element.

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let txt = "";
numbers.forEach(myFunction);

function myFunction(value, index, array) {
  txt += value + "<br>";
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:

content.text: The example above uses only the value parameter. The example can be rewritten to:
content.html: The example above uses only the value parameter. The example can be rewritten to:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let txt = "";
numbers.forEach(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  txt += value + "<br>";
}

content.text: JavaScript Array map()
The map() method creates a new array by performing a function on each array element.
content.html: The map() method creates a new array by performing a function on each array element.

content.text: The map() method does not execute the function for array elements without values.
content.html: The map() method does not execute the function for array elements without values.

content.text: The map() method does not change the original array.
content.html: The map() method does not change the original array.

content.text: This example multiplies each array value by 2:
content.html: This example multiplies each array value by 2:

content.code_html:
const numbers1 = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
const numbers2 = numbers1.map(myFunction);

function myFunction(value, index, array) {
  return value * 2;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:

content.text: When a callback function uses only the value parameter, the index and array parameters can be omitted:
content.html: When a callback function uses only the value parameter, the index and array parameters can be omitted:

content.code_html:
const numbers1 = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
const numbers2 = numbers1.map(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  return value * 2;
}

content.text: JavaScript Array flatMap()
ES2019 added the Array flatMap() method to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2019 added the Array flatMap() method to JavaScript.

content.text: The flatMap() method first maps all elements of an array and then creates a new array by flattening the array.
content.html: The flatMap() method first maps all elements of an array and then creates a new array by flattening the array.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap((x) => x * 2);

content.code:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap((x) => x * 2);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap((x) => x * 2);

content.code_html:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap((x) => x * 2);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap((x) => x * 2);

content.text: Browser Support
JavaScript Array flatMap() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: JavaScript Array flatMap() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 69 Edge 79 Firefox 62 Safari 12 Opera 56
Sep 2018 Jan 2020 Sep 2018 Sep 2018 Sep 2018

content.text: JavaScript Array filter()
The filter() method creates a new array with array elements that pass a test.
content.html: The filter() method creates a new array with array elements that pass a test.

content.text: This example creates a new array from elements with a value larger than 18:
content.html: This example creates a new array from elements with a value larger than 18:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
const over18 = numbers.filter(myFunction);

function myFunction(value, index, array) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:

content.text: In the example above, the callback function does not use the index and array parameters, so they can be omitted:
content.html: In the example above, the callback function does not use the index and array parameters, so they can be omitted:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
const over18 = numbers.filter(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: JavaScript Array reduce()
The reduce() method runs a function on each array element to produce (reduce it to) a single value.
content.html: The reduce() method runs a function on each array element to produce (reduce it to) a single value.

content.text: The reduce() method works from left-to-right in the array. See also reduceRight() .
content.html: The reduce() method works from left-to-right in the array. See also reduceRight().

content.text: The reduce() method does not reduce the original array.
content.html: The reduce() method does not reduce the original array.

content.text: This example finds the sum of all numbers in an array:
content.html: This example finds the sum of all numbers in an array:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let sum = numbers.reduce(myFunction);

function myFunction(total, value, index, array) {
  return total + value;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 4 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 4 arguments:

content.text: The example above does not use the index and array parameters. It can be rewritten to:
content.html: The example above does not use the index and array parameters. It can be rewritten to:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let sum = numbers.reduce(myFunction);

function myFunction(total, value) {
  return total + value;
}

content.text: The reduce() method can accept an initial value:
content.html: The reduce() method can accept an initial value:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let sum = numbers.reduce(myFunction, 100);

function myFunction(total, value) {
  return total + value;
}

content.text: JavaScript Array reduceRight()
The reduceRight() method runs a function on each array element to produce (reduce it to) a single value.
content.html: The reduceRight() method runs a function on each array element to produce (reduce it to) a single value.

content.text: The reduceRight() works from right-to-left in the array. See also reduce() .
content.html: The reduceRight() works from right-to-left in the array. See also reduce().

content.text: The reduceRight() method does not reduce the original array.
content.html: The reduceRight() method does not reduce the original array.

content.text: This example finds the sum of all numbers in an array:
content.html: This example finds the sum of all numbers in an array:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let sum = numbers.reduceRight(myFunction);

function myFunction(total, value, index, array) {
  return total + value;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 4 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 4 arguments:

content.text: The example above does not use the index and array parameters. It can be rewritten to:
content.html: The example above does not use the index and array parameters. It can be rewritten to:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let sum = numbers.reduceRight(myFunction);

function myFunction(total, value) {
  return total + value;
}

content.text: JavaScript Array every()
The every() method checks if all array values pass a test.
content.html: The every() method checks if all array values pass a test.

content.text: This example checks if all array values are larger than 18:
content.html: This example checks if all array values are larger than 18:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let allOver18 = numbers.every(myFunction);

function myFunction(value, index, array) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:

content.text: When a callback function uses the first parameter only (value), the other parameters can be omitted:
content.html: When a callback function uses the first parameter only (value), the other parameters can be omitted:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let allOver18 = numbers.every(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: JavaScript Array some()
The some() method checks if some array values pass a test.
content.html: The some() method checks if some array values pass a test.

content.text: This example checks if some array values are larger than 18:
content.html: This example checks if some array values are larger than 18:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let someOver18 = numbers.some(myFunction);

function myFunction(value, index, array) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:

content.text: JavaScript Array.from()
The Array.from() method returns an Array object from any object with a length property or any iterable object.
content.html: The Array.from() method returns an Array object from any object with a length property or any iterable object.

content.code: Array.from("ABCDEFG");
content.code_html: Array.from("ABCDEFG");

content.text: Browser Support
from() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).
content.html: from() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).

content.text: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:
content.html: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 51 Edge 15 Firefox 54 Safari 10 Opera 38
May 2016 Apr 2017 Jun 2017 Sep 2016 Jun 2016

content.text: from() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: from() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: JavaScript Array keys()
The Array.keys() method returns an Array Iterator object with the keys of an array.
content.html: The Array.keys() method returns an Array Iterator object with the keys of an array.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
const keys = fruits.keys();

for (let x of keys) {
  text += x + "<br>";
}

content.text: Browser Support
keys() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).
content.html: keys() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).

content.text: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:
content.html: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 51 Edge 15 Firefox 54 Safari 10 Opera 38
May 2016 Apr 2017 Jun 2017 Sep 2016 Jun 2016

content.text: keys() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: keys() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: JavaScript Array entries()

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
const f = fruits.entries();

for (let x of f) {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML += x;
}

content.text: The entries() method returns an Array Iterator object with key/value pairs:
content.html: The entries() method returns an Array Iterator object with key/value pairs:

content.text: [0, "Banana"] [1, "Orange"] [2, "Apple"] [3, "Mango"]
content.html:
[0, "Banana"]
[1, "Orange"]
[2, "Apple"]
[3, "Mango"]

content.text: The entries() method does not change the original array.
content.html: The entries() method does not change the original array.

content.text: Browser Support
entries() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).
content.html: entries() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).

content.text: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:
content.html: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 51 Edge 15 Firefox 54 Safari 10 Opera 38
May 2016 Apr 2017 Jun 2017 Sep 2016 Jun 2016

content.text: entries() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: entries() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: JavaScript Array with() Method
ES2023 added the Array with() method as a safe way to update elements in an array without altering the original array.
content.html: ES2023 added the Array with() method as a safe way to update elements in an array without altering the original array.

content.code:
const months = ["Januar", "Februar", "Mar", "April"];
const myMonths = months.with(2, "March");
content.code_html:
const months = ["Januar", "Februar", "Mar", "April"];
const myMonths = months.with(2, "March");

content.text: JavaScript Array Spread (...)
The ... operator expands an iterable (like an array) into more elements:
content.html: The ... operator expands an iterable (like an array) into more elements:

content.code_html:
const q1 = ["Jan", "Feb", "Mar"];
const q2 = ["Apr", "May", "Jun"];
const q3 = ["Jul", "Aug", "Sep"];
const q4 = ["Oct", "Nov", "Des"];

const year = [...q1, ...q2, ...q3, ...q4];

content.text: Browser Support
... is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).
content.html: ... is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).

content.text: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:
content.html: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 51 Edge 15 Firefox 54 Safari 10 Opera 38
May 2016 Apr 2017 Jun 2017 Sep 2016 Jun 2016

content.text: ... is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: ... is not supported in Internet Explorer.

For a complete Array reference, go to our:
content.html: For a complete Array reference, go to our:

content.html: Complete JavaScript Array Reference.

content.text: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Array properties and methods.
content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Array properties and methods.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: const x = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25]; let y = x.every(myfunc); function myfunc(val) { return val > 20; } What will the result of the y ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
const x = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
let y = x.every(myfunc);
function myfunc(val) {
  return val > 20;
}
What will the result of the y?
